ray.rage

Class Engine

  • java.lang.Object
    • ray.rage.Engine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Manageable

    public final class Engine
extends java.lang.Object
implements Manageable
    The engine class is a singleton object and the main point of access to the framework and its sub-systems.

    From here, the application can gain access to other framework components including render-systems, scene-management, and other functionality at a higher level of abstraction. It also doubles as an example of the Facade pattern. This allows users to more easily do certain things, while also making lower-level sub-system interfaces accessible.

    Note that this class avoids following the singleton pattern to avoid introducing global objects/states into the framework and the applications that use it.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera

      • notifyElapsedTimeMillis

        public void notifyElapsedTimeMillis(float elapsedTimeMs)
        Notifies the engine about the elapsed time since the last update.

        WARNING: This method is meant to be used internally by the framework and not by game clients. Use directly only if you really know what you're doing.

        Parameters:
        elapsedTimeMs - The elapsed time, in milliseconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the time is negative.

      • getElapsedTimeMillis

        public float getElapsedTimeMillis()
        Gets the elapsed time since the last set of updates.
        Returns:
        The elapsed time, in milliseconds.
        See Also:
        notifyElapsedTimeMillis(float)

      • registerSceneManager

        public void registerSceneManager(SceneManager sm)
        Registers a new scene-manager for later use. This may be any built-in implementation or one provided by you. If providing your own, be sure to use the appropriate environment.

        To actually use the scene-manager, it needs to be made "active" with setActiveSceneManager(SceneManager.Environment).

        Parameters:
        sm - The scene-manager to be registered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If a scene-manager of type environment has already been registered.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the scene-manager is null.
        See Also:
        setActiveSceneManager(SceneManager.Environment)

      • setActiveSceneManager

        public void setActiveSceneManager(SceneManager.Environment env)
        Specifies the environment that should be in use by the system to actively manage scenes.
        Parameters:
        env - The environment to use.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If a scene-manager of the specified environment has not been registered.
        See Also:
        registerSceneManager(SceneManager)

      • getSceneManager

        public SceneManager getSceneManager()
        Gets the scene-manager that's currently active. Otherwise, null
        Returns:
        The active scene-manager. Otherwise null.

      • registerRenderSystem

        public void registerRenderSystem(RenderSystem rs)
        Registers a new render-system for later use. This may be any built-in implementation or one provided by you.

        To actually use the system, it needs to be made "active" with setActiveRenderSystem(RenderSystem.API).

        Parameters:
        rs - The render-system to be registered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If a render-system of type RenderSystem.API has already been registered.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the render-system is null.
        See Also:
        setActiveRenderSystem(RenderSystem.API)

      • setActiveRenderSystem

        public void setActiveRenderSystem(RenderSystem.API api)
        Specifies the RenderSystem.API that should be in use by the system to actively render frames.
        Parameters:
        api - The RenderSystem.API to use.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If a renderer of type RenderSystem.API has not been registered.
        See Also:
        registerRenderSystem(RenderSystem)
